original: Puggalapaññatti
analyzed: puggala paññatti
translated: Description of Persons

original: Niddesa
analyzed: niddesa
translated: The Niddesa

original: 5. Pañcakapuggalapaññatti
analyzed: pañcaka puggala paññatti
translated: The Description of Five Kinds of Persons

original: Tatra yvāyaṁ puggalo ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ
analyzed: tatra yvā ayam puggalaḥ ārabhati ca vippaṭisārī ca hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimutti
translated: “There is the case where a certain person is one who makes others angry and is also one who regrets it afterwards.

original: yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not understand as it really is that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, wherein those evil, unskillful qualities that have arisen come to complete cessation.

original: so evamassa vacanīyo—
analyzed: saḥ evam assa vacanīyaḥ
translated: He should be told,

original: “āyasmato kho ārambhajā āsavā saṁvijjanti, vippaṭisārajā āsavā pavaḍḍhanti.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ kho ārambha jāḥ āsavā savijjanti vippaṭisāra jāḥ āsavā pavaḍḍhanti
translated: ‘Venerable sir, effluents born of making others angry are found in you. Effluents born of regret are increasing.

original: Sādhu vatāyasmā ārambhaje āsave pahāya vippaṭisāraje āsave paṭivinodetvā cittaṁ paññañca bhāvetu.
analyzed: sādhu vata ayasmai ārambha je āsave pahāya vippaṭisāra je āsave paṭivinodetvā cittam paññam ca bhāvetu
translated: It would be good if you would abandon the effluents born of making others angry and would clear away the effluents born of regret.

original: Evamāyasmā amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: evam āyasmai amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: In this way you will be like the fifth person.’

original: Tatra yvāyaṁ puggalo ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ
analyzed: tatra yvā ayam puggalaḥ ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimutti
translated: “There is the case where a certain person is one who makes others angry but is not one who regrets it afterwards.

original: yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not understand as it really is that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, wherein those evil, unskillful qualities that have arisen come to complete cessation.

original: so evamassa vacanīyo—
analyzed: saḥ evam assa vacanīyaḥ
translated: He should be told,

original: “āyasmato kho ārambhajā āsavā saṁvijjanti, vippaṭisārajā āsavā nappavaḍḍhanti.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ kho ārambha jāḥ āsavā savijjanti vippaṭisāra jāḥ āsavā na pavaḍḍhanti
translated: “You have the defilements that arise from resentment, but not the defilements that arise from remorse.

original: Sādhu vatāyasmā ārambhaje āsave pahāya cittaṁ paññañca bhāvetu.
analyzed: sādhu vata ayasmai ārambha je āsave pahāya cittam paññam ca bhāvetu
translated: It would be good if you would give up the defilements that arise from resentment and develop your mind and wisdom.

original: Evamāyasmā amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: evam āyasmai amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: In this way you will be the equal of the fifth person.”🔽The person who doesn’t resent but is remorseful,

original: Tatra yvāyaṁ puggalo na ārabhati vippaṭisārī hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ
analyzed: tatra yvā ayam puggalaḥ na ārabhati vippaṭisārī hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimutti
translated: and who doesn’t understand as it really is the freedom of mind and freedom by wisdom

original: yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: where those bad unwholesome qualities that have arisen cease without trace,

original: so evamassa vacanīyo—
analyzed: saḥ evam assa vacanīyaḥ
translated: should be told,

original: “āyasmato kho ārambhajā āsavā na saṁvijjanti, vippaṭisārajā āsavā pavaḍḍhanti.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ kho ārambha jāḥ āsavāḥ na savijjanti vippaṭisāra jāḥ āsavā pavaḍḍhanti
translated: “You don’t have the defilements that arise from resentment, but you have the defilements that arise from remorse.

original: Sādhu vatāyasmā vippaṭisāraje āsave paṭivinodetvā cittaṁ paññañca bhāvetu.
analyzed: sādhu vata ayasmai vippaṭisāra je āsave paṭivinodetvā cittam paññam ca bhāvetu
translated: It would be good if you would resolve the defilements that arise from remorse and develop your mind and wisdom.

original: Evamāyasmā amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: evam āyasmai amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: In this way you will be the equal of the fifth person.”

original: Tatra yvāyaṁ puggalo na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti, tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ
analyzed: tatra yvā ayam puggalaḥ na ārabhati na vippaṭisārī hoti tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimutti
translated: Herein, the person who does not make an effort and is not remorseful, and who has attained both the freedom of mind and the freedom through discernment,

original: yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: “When a person doesn’t get angry or feel revulsion, but doesn’t understand as it really is the freedom of mind, the freedom through wisdom where those bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen cease without remainder,

original: so evamassa vacanīyo—
analyzed: saḥ evam assa vacanīyaḥ
translated: he should be told,

original: “āyasmato kho ārambhajā āsavā na saṁvijjanti, vippaṭisārajā āsavā nappavaḍḍhanti.
analyzed: āyasmataḥ kho ārambha jāḥ āsavāḥ na savijjanti vippaṭisāra jāḥ āsavāḥ na pavaḍḍhanti
translated: ‘Sir, you don’t have effluents that arise from getting angry. You don’t have effluents that increase from feeling revulsion.

original: Sādhu vatāyasmā cittaṁ paññañca bhāvetu.
analyzed: sādhu vata ayasmai cittam paññam ca bhāvetu
translated: It would be good if you would develop your mind and wisdom.

original: Evamāyasmā amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamo bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: evam āyasmai amunā pañcamena puggalena samasamaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: In this way you will be equal to the fifth person.’

original: Ime cattāro puggalā amunā pañcamena puggalena evaṁ ovadiyamānā evaṁ anusāsiyamānā anupubbena āsavānaṁ khayaṁ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: ime cattāro puggalāḥ amunā pañcamena puggalena evam ovadiyamānāḥ evam anusāsiyamānāḥ anupubbena āsavānam khayam pāpuṇanti
translated: When these four people are instructed and advised like this, they eventually reach the ending of the effluents.

original: Kathañca puggalo datvā avajānāti?
analyzed: kathañca puggalaḥ da tvā avajānāti
translated: “And how does a person despise after giving?

original: Idhekacco puggalo yassa puggalassa deti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ, tassa evaṁ hoti—
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ yassa puggalassa deti cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāra tassa evam hoti
translated: It’s when a person gives a gift to someone, thinking,

original: “ahaṁ dammi, ayaṁ paṭiggaṇhātī”ti, tamenaṁ datvā avajānāti.
analyzed: aham dammi ayam paṭiggaṇhāti iti tam enam da tvā avajānāti
translated: ‘I give, he receives,’ then after giving, he despises him.

original: Evaṁ puggalo datvā avajānāti.
analyzed: evam puggalaḥ da tvā avajānāti
translated: This is how a person despises after giving.

original: Kathañca puggalo saṁvāsena avajānāti?
analyzed: kathañca puggalaḥ sa vāsena avajānāti
translated: “And how does a person despise through association?

original: Idhekacco puggalo yena puggalena saddhiṁ saṁvasati dve vā tīṇi vā vassāni, tamenaṁ saṁvāsena avajānāti.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ yena puggalena saddhim savasati dve vā tīṇi vā vassāni tam enam sa vāsena avajānāti
translated: There is the case where a person associates with another for two or three years. He despises him through association.

original: Evaṁ puggalo saṁvāsena avajānāti.
analyzed: evam puggalaḥ sa vāsena avajānāti
translated: This is how a person despises through association.

original: Kathañca puggalo ādheyyamukho hoti?
analyzed: kathañca puggalaḥ ādheyya mukhaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a person one who receives respectfully?

original: Idhekacco puggalo parassa vaṇṇe vā avaṇṇe vā bhāsiyamāne khippaññeva adhimuccitā hoti.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ puggalo parassa vaṇṇe vā avaṇṇe vā bhāsiyamāne khippaññā iva adhimuccitā hoti
translated: There is the case where a person, when another’s praise or blame is being spoken, quickly assents to it.

original: Evaṁ puggalo ādheyyamukho hoti.
analyzed: evam puggalaḥ ādheyya mukhaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a person is one who receives respectfully.

original: Kathañca puggalo lolo hoti?
analyzed: kathañca puggalaḥ lolaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a person fickle?

original: Idhekacco puggalo ittarasaddho hoti ittarabhattī ittarapemo ittarappasādo.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ ittara saddhaḥ hoti ittara bhattī ittara pemo ittara ppasādo
translated: There is the case where a person is of little confidence, little commitment, little assent, & little appreciation.

original: Evaṁ puggalo lolo hoti.
analyzed: evam puggalaḥ lolaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a person is fickle.

original: Kathañca puggalo mando momūho hoti?
analyzed: kathañca puggalaḥ mandaḥ momūhaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a person dull & confused?

original: Idhekacco puggalo kusalākusale dhamme na jānāti, sāvajjānavajje dhamme na jānāti, hīnappaṇīte dhamme na jānāti, kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāge dhamme na jānāti.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ kusala akusale dhamme na jānāti sāvajja anavajje dhamme na jānāti hīna ppaṇīte dhamme na jānāti kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāge dhamme na jānāti
translated: Here someone does not know what is wholesome and what is unwholesome, what is blameable and what is blameless, what is to be practiced and what is not to be practiced, or what has been done and what has not been done.

original: Evaṁ puggalo mando momūho hoti.
analyzed: evam puggalaḥ mandaḥ momūhaḥ hoti
translated: This is how one is dull and stupid.

original: Tattha katame pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā?
analyzed: tattha katame pañca puggalā
translated: Herein, what are the five kinds of persons similar to warriors?

original: Pañca yodhājīvā—
analyzed: pañca yodhājīvā
translated: There are five kinds of warriors:

original: idhekacco yodhājīvo rajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ yodha ājīvaḥ rajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu
translated: Here, some warrior, on seeing the cloud of dust, sinks, founders, does not brace himself, and cannot enter the battle.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco yodhājīvo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ikaccaḥ yodhājīvaḥ hoti
translated: This kind of warrior exists in the world.

original: Ayaṁ paṭhamo yodhājīvo santo saṁvijjamāno lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: ayam paṭhamaḥ yodhājīvaḥ santo sa vijjamāno lokasmi
translated: This is the first kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ, api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ.
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati api ca kho dhajaggañca iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu
translated: Again, some warrior can endure the cloud of dust, but on seeing the crests of the standards, he sinks, founders, does not brace himself, and cannot enter the battle.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco yodhājīvo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ikaccaḥ yodhājīvaḥ hoti
translated: This kind of warrior exists in the world.

original: Ayaṁ dutiyo yodhājīvo santo saṁvijjamāno lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: ayam dutiyaḥ yodhājīvaḥ santo sa vijjamānaḥ lokasmi
translated: This is the second kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ, api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ.🔽Evarūpopi idhekacco yodhājīvo hoti.
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajagga api ca kho ussāraṇañca iva sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu  evarūpaḥ api idha ikaccaḥ yodhājīvaḥ hoti
translated: “Again, some warrior sees the top of the banner or the top of the standard and hears the uproar, but on hearing and seeing this, he desists, falls away, and retrogresses.

original: Ayaṁ tatiyo yodhājīvo santo saṁvijjamāno lokasmiṁ.🔽Puna caparaṁ idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ, api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati.
analyzed: ayam tatiyaḥ yodhājīvaḥ santo sa vijjamānaḥ lokasmi  puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇa api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati
translated: Such is the third kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco yodhājīvo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ikaccaḥ yodhājīvaḥ hoti
translated: “Again, some warrior sees the top of the banner or the top of the standard and hears the uproar, but on hearing and seeing this, he does not desist, he does not fall away or retrogress, but he is slain or slain or wounded.

original: Ayaṁ catuttho yodhājīvo santo saṁvijjamāno lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: ayam catutthaḥ yodhājīvo santo sa vijjamāno lokasmi
translated: Such is the fourth kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ sahati sampahāraṁ.
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇam sahati sampahāra
translated: “Again, some warrior sees the top of the banner or the top of the standard and hears the uproar, but on hearing and seeing this, he does not desist, he does not fall away or retrogress, nor is he slain or wounded.

original: So taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ ajjhāvasati.
analyzed: saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva saṅgāma sīsam ajjhāvasati
translated: Having conquered that battle, he dwells as the victor over the slain.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco yodhājīvo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ikaccaḥ yodhājīvaḥ hoti
translated: Such is the fifth kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Ayaṁ pañcamo yodhājīvo santo saṁvijjamāno lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: ayam pañcamaḥ yodhājīvaḥ santo sa vijjamānaḥ lokasmi
translated: This is the fifth kind of warrior found in the world.

original: Ime pañca yodhājīvā santo saṁvijjamānā lokasmiṁ.
analyzed: ime pañca yodhājīvā santaḥ sa vijjamānā lokasmi
translated: These are the five kinds of warriors found in the world.

original: Evamevaṁ pañcime yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: evam evam pañcime yodha ājīva upamā puggalā santaḥ sa vijjamānā bhikkhūsu
translated: “So too, these five kinds of persons similar to warriors are found existing in the world.

original: Katame pañca?
analyzed: katame pañca
translated: What are the five?

original: Idhekacco bhikkhu rajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu rajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: “Here, some bhikkhu, on merely seeing a dust cloud, desists, turns back, and does not enter into discussion. He is incapable of maintaining a spiritual life. He falls into idleness and fails in the training.

original: Kimassa rajaggasmiṁ?
analyzed: kim assa rajaggasmi
translated: What is his dust cloud?

original: Idha bhikkhu suṇāti—
analyzed: idha bhikkhu suṇāti
translated: Here, a bhikkhu hears thus:

original: “asukasmiṁ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā”ti.
analyzed: asukasmim nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatā ati
translated: ‘In such and such a village or town the women or girls are beautiful, attractive, graceful, possessing supreme beauty of complexion.’

original: So taṁ sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: saḥ tam sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya āvattati
translated: On hearing this, he desists, turns back, and does not enter into discussion. He is incapable of maintaining a spiritual life. He falls into idleness and fails in the training.

original: Idamassa rajaggasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam assa rajaggasmi
translated: This is his dust cloud.🔽“Again, some bhikkhu, on merely hearing the sound of voices, desists, turns back, and does not enter into discussion. He is incapable of maintaining a spiritual life. He falls into idleness and fails in the training.🔽What is his sound of voices?

original: Seyyathāpi so yodhājīvo rajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ, tathūpamo ayaṁ puggalo.
analyzed: sa iyyathā api saḥ yodha ājīvaḥ rajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu tathūpamaḥ ayam puggalo
translated: Just like a warrior who, on seeing a cloud of dust, is terrified, shaken, and frightened, and who, on seeing the top of a standard, collapses and falls, unable to enter the battle, so too is this person.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: Such a person is found among the bhikkhus.

original: Ayaṁ paṭhamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ayam paṭhamaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalaḥ santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the first kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ, api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati🔽visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu sahati api ca kho dhajaggaññā iva disvā sasīdati  visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā
translated: “Again, a certain bhikkhu can endure a cloud of dust, but on seeing the top of a standard, he collapses and falls,🔽unable to maintain the spiritual life. He reveals his weakness in the training,

original: sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: renounces the training, and reverts to the lower life.

original: Kimassa dhajaggasmiṁ?
analyzed: kimassa dhajaggasmi
translated: What is the top of a standard for him?

original: Idha bhikkhu na heva kho suṇāti—
analyzed: idha bhikkhu na ha iva kho suṇāti
translated: It is this: a bhikkhu does not hear that

original: “asukasmiṁ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā🔽paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā”ti, api ca kho sāmaṁ passati itthiṁ vā kumāriṁ
analyzed: asukasmim nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā kumārī vā abhirūpā dassanīyā pāsādikā 🔽paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya samannāgatā ati api ca kho sāmam passati itthim vā kumāri
translated: in such and such a village or town a woman or a maiden is well proportioned, pleasing, beautiful, possessing supreme beauty of complexion,🔽but he sees her with his own eyes.

original: vā abhirūpaṁ dassanīyaṁ pāsādikaṁ paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgataṁ.
analyzed: vā abhirūpam dassanīyam pāsādikam paramāya vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya samannāgata
translated: He is handsome, good-looking, pleasing, possessing supreme beauty of complexion.

original: So taṁ disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: saḥ tam disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: On seeing her, he becomes lustful, loses his persistence, his energy, and his mindfulness, and he is unable to continue in the spiritual life.

original: Idamassa dhajaggasmiṁ.
analyzed: idamassa dhajaggasmi
translated: This is his banner.

original: Seyyathāpi so yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ, api ca kho dhajaggaññeva disvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ, tathūpamo ayaṁ puggalo.
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati api ca kho dhajaggañca iva disvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu tathūpamaḥ ayam puggalo
translated: Just as that warrior is able to endure the cloud of dust, but on seeing the top of the standard, he becomes frightened, loses his persistence, his energy, and his mindfulness, and is unable to enter the battle, so too is this person.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: There is this type of person found among the bhikkhus.

original: Ayaṁ dutiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ayam dutiyaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the second type of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ, api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu sahati rajaggam sahati dhajagga api ca kho
translated: “Again, some bhikkhu is able to endure the cloud of dust and the top of the standard, but on hearing the shout

original: sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ
analyzed: sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu
translated: he becomes frightened, loses his persistence, his energy, and his mindfulness, and is unable to continue in the spiritual life.

original: āvikatvā sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: āvikatvā sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and then disrobes, returning to the lower life.

original: Kimassa ussāraṇāya?
analyzed: kim assa ussāraṇāya
translated: What is his boast?

original: Idha bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā ūhasati ullapati ujjagghati uppaṇḍeti.🔽So mātugāmena ūhasiyamāno ullapiyamāno ujjagghiyamāno uppaṇḍiyamāno saṁsīdati visīdati
analyzed: idha bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā ūhasati ullapati ujjagghati uppaṇḍeti  saḥ mātugāmena sasīdati visīdati
translated: It’s when a monk who has gone to the wilderness, to the root of a tree, or to an empty building is approached by a woman, who then teases, torments, and persecutes him.

original: na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhādubbalyaṁ āvikatvā sikkhaṁ
analyzed: na santhambhati na sakkoti brahmacariyam sandhāretu sikkhā dubbalyam āvikatvā sikkha
translated: And he, being teased, tormented, and persecuted by that woman, sinks, founders, and fails to keep going. He’s not able to maintain the spiritual life. He announces his weakness in the training,

original: paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati
translated: and then disrobes, returning to the lower life.

original: Idamassa ussāraṇāya.
analyzed: idam assa ussāraṇāya
translated: This is his boast.

original: Seyyathāpi so yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ, api ca kho ussāraṇaññeva sutvā saṁsīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmaṁ otarituṁ, tathūpamo ayaṁ puggalo.
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajagga api ca kho ussāraṇañca iva sutvā sasīdati visīdati na santhambhati na sakkoti saṅgāmam otaritu tathūpamaḥ ayam puggalo
translated: Just like the warrior who can endure the cloud of dust and the top of the standard, but who sinks, founders, and fails to keep going when the shout of command is heard, so too is this person.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: There are some individuals like this in the world.

original: Ayaṁ tatiyo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ayam tatiyaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalaḥ santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the third kind of person similar to a warrior found among the monks.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ, api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati.
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇe api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati
translated: “There is the case where a certain person can endure a division of troops, a division of elephants, a division of horses, a division of chariots, a division of foot soldiers, the sound of a division of troops, the sound of conches, the sound of war-drums, the sound of tambourines, the sound of cymbals, the sound of flutes, the sound of singing, the sound of hand-clapping, the sound of men, the sound of women, the sound of boys, the sound of girls, the sound of being struck with one’s hand, the sound of being struck with a blade of grass.

original: Kimassa sampahārasmiṁ?
analyzed: kim assa sampahārasmi
translated: “What is his defeat?

original: Idha bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati
translated: “There is the case where a certain person, gone to the wilderness, to the shade of a tree, or to an empty building, is overcome with sleepiness.

original: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno sikkhaṁ appaccakkhāya dubbalyaṁ anāvikatvā methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevati.
analyzed: saḥ mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamānaḥ abhinipajjiyamānaḥ ajjhotthariyamānaḥ sikkham ap paccakkhāya dubbalyam an āvikatvā methunam dhammam paṭisevati
translated: “He, overcome with sleepiness, having not fulfilled the training, having not attained the goal for which one goes forth from the home life into homelessness, engages in sexual intercourse.

original: Idamassa sampahārasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam assa sampahārasmi
translated: “This is his defeat.

original: Seyyathāpi so yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ, api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati, tathūpamo ayaṁ puggalo.
analyzed: seyyathā api saḥ yodha ājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇa api ca kho sampahāre haññati byāpajjati tathūpamaḥ ayam puggalaḥ
translated: “Just as the warrior-noble can endure a division of troops, a division of elephants, a division of horses, a division of chariots, a division of foot soldiers, the sound of a division of troops, the sound of conches, the sound of war-drums, the sound of tambourines, the sound of cymbals, the sound of flutes, the sound of singing, the sound of hand-clapping, the sound of men, the sound of women, the sound of boys, the sound of girls, the sound of being struck with one’s hand, the sound of being struck with a blade of grass, but is killed or wounded by a concealed arrow, so too is this person.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: There is the case where a certain person is like this.

original: Ayaṁ catuttho yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ayam catutthaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the fourth type of person similar to a warrior-noble found among the monks.

original: Puna caparaṁ idhekacco bhikkhu sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ sahati sampahāraṁ.
analyzed: puna ca param idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇam sahati sampahāra
translated: “Again, a certain person is able to endure a division of troops, a division of elephants, a division of horses, a division of chariots, a division of foot soldiers, the sound of a division of troops, the sound of a division of elephants, the sound of a division of horses, the sound of a division of chariots, the sound of a division of foot soldiers, the dust raised by a division of troops, the dust raised by a division of elephants, the dust raised by a division of horses, the dust raised by a division of chariots, the dust raised by a division of foot soldiers, the clash of a division of troops, the clash of a division of elephants, the clash of a division of horses, the clash of a division of chariots, the clash of a division of foot soldiers.

original: So taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ ajjhāvasati.
analyzed: saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva saṅgāma sīsam ajjhāvasati
translated: Having conquered that battle, having won that battle, he dwells as the victor in that very battle.

original: Kimassa saṅgāmavijayasmiṁ?
analyzed: kim assa saṅgām avijayasmi
translated: What is his victory in battle?

original: Idha bhikkhuṁ araññagataṁ vā rukkhamūlagataṁ vā suññāgāragataṁ vā mātugāmo upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati.
analyzed: idha bhikkhum arañña gatam vā rukkha mūla gatam vā suññāgāra gatam vā mātugāmaḥ upasaṅkamitvā abhinisīdati abhinipajjati ajjhottharati
translated: Here, when a bhikkhu has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, a woman approaches him, sits down or lies down next to him, embraces him, and kisses him.

original: So mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamāno abhinipajjiyamāno ajjhotthariyamāno viniveṭhetvā vinimocetvā yena kāmaṁ pakkamati.
analyzed: saḥ mātugāmena abhinisīdiyamānaḥ abhinipajjiyamānaḥ ajjhotthariyamānaḥ viniveṭhetvā vinimocetvā yena kāmam pakkamati
translated: The bhikkhu does not sit or lie down with her, does not embrace or kiss her, but having turned back and freed himself, he goes away wherever he likes.

original: So vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: so vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: He frequents a solitary bed and seat in the forest, at the foot of a tree, or in an empty hut, in a mountainous region, in the midst of thickets, or in a glen.

original: So araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: When he has gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, he sits down, folding his legs crosswise, straightening his body, and establishing mindfulness in front of him.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned longing for the world, he dwells with a mind free from longing; he purifies his mind from longing.

original: byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti;🔽thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti  thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned ill will and hatred, he dwells with a mind free from ill will, compassionate toward all living beings; he purifies his mind from ill will and hatred.🔽Having abandoned dullness and drowsiness, he dwells free from dullness and drowsiness, percipient of light, mindful and clearly comprehending; he purifies his mind from dullness and drowsiness.

original: uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti;
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned restlessness and remorse, he dwells without agitation, with a mind inwardly peaceful; he purifies his mind from restlessness and remorse.

original: vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: Having abandoned doubt, he dwells having gone beyond doubt, unperplexed about wholesome qualities; he purifies his mind from doubt.

original: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe vivicceva kāmehi
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe vivicca iva kāmehi
translated: He abandons the five hindrances,🔽and then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters and dwells in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination.

original: vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ🔽upasampajja viharati;
analyzed: vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhāna  upasampajja viharati
translated: With the subsiding of thought and examination, he enters and dwells in the second jhāna, which has internal placidity and unification of mind and consists of rapture and pleasure born of concentration, without thought and examination.

original: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…🔽tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ dutiyam jhānam  tatiyam jhānam
translated: With the fading away as well of rapture, he dwells equanimous and, mindful and clearly comprehending, he experiences pleasure with the body; he enters and dwells in the third jhāna of which the noble ones declare: ‘He is equanimous, mindful, one who dwells happily.’

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and displeasure, he enters and dwells in the fourth jhāna, neither pain-ful nor pleasant, which has purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.🔽So “idaṁ dukkhan”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, “ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti  saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽He understands as it really is: “This is suffering”; he understands as it really is: “This is the origin of suffering”;

original: “ayaṁ dukkhanirodho”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, “ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā”ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati 🔽yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: “This is the cessation of suffering”; he understands as it really is: “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.”

original: “ime āsavā”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, “ayaṁ āsavasamudayo”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints.’ He understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints.’

original: “ayaṁ āsavanirodho”ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, “ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā”ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints.’ He understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Idamassa saṅgāmavijayasmiṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi so yodhājīvo sahati rajaggaṁ sahati dhajaggaṁ sahati ussāraṇaṁ sahati
analyzed: idam assa saṅgām avijayasmi  sa iyyathā api saḥ yodhājīvaḥ sahati rajaggam sahati dhajaggam sahati ussāraṇam sahati
translated: This is his victory in battle.

original: sampahāraṁ, so taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tameva saṅgāmasīsaṁ ajjhāvasati,🔽tathūpamo ayaṁ puggalo.
analyzed: sampahāra saḥ tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tam eva saṅgāma sīsam ajjhāvasati  tathūpamaḥ ayam puggalaḥ
translated: Just as that warrior is one who can endure the cloud of dust, the crests of the standards, the shout, and the blow, and who, having triumphed in that battle, emerges victorious and settles at the head of the battlefield,🔽so too is this person.

original: Evarūpopi idhekacco puggalo hoti.
analyzed: evarūpaḥ api idha ekaccaḥ puggalaḥ hoti
translated: Such a person is found here.

original: Ayaṁ pañcamo yodhājīvūpamo puggalo santo saṁvijjamāno bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ayam pañcamaḥ yodha ājīva upamaḥ puggalo santaḥ sa vijjamānaḥ bhikkhūsu
translated: This is the fifth kind of person similar to a warrior found among the bhikkhus.

original: Ime pañca yodhājīvūpamā puggalā santo saṁvijjamānā bhikkhūsu.
analyzed: ime pañca yodha ājīva upamā puggalā santaḥ savijjamānā bhikkhūsu
translated: These are the five kinds of persons similar to warriors found among the bhikkhus.

original: Tattha katame pañca piṇḍapātikā?🔽Mandattā momūhattā piṇḍapātiko hoti, pāpiccho icchāpakato piṇḍapātiko hoti, ummādā
analyzed: tattha katame pañca  mandattā momūhattā piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti pāpicchaḥ icchā pakataḥ piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti ummādā
translated: Herein, what are the five kinds of alms-food eaters?

original: cittavikkhepā piṇḍapātiko hoti, “vaṇṇitaṁ buddhehi buddhasāvakehī”ti piṇḍapātiko🔽hoti, api ca appicchataṁyeva nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva nissāya
analyzed: citta vikkhepā piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti vaṇṇitam buddhehi buddha sāvakehi iti piṇḍapātiko  hoti api ca appiccha tayā iva nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva nissāya
translated: One is an alms-food eater out of foolishness and folly; one is an alms-food eater because of desire and greed; one is an alms-food eater because of madness and mindlessness; one is an alms-food eater because “It is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples.”

original: idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya piṇḍapātiko hoti.🔽Tatra yvāyaṁ piṇḍapātiko appicchataṁyeva nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva🔽nissāya idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya piṇḍapātiko, ayaṁ imesaṁ pañcannaṁ piṇḍapātikānaṁ
analyzed: idam atthitayā iva nissāya piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti  tatra yvā ayam piṇḍapātikaḥ appiccha tayā iva nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva  nissāya idam atthitayā iva nissāya piṇḍapātikaḥ ayam imesam pañcannam
translated: One is an alms-food eater depending only on fewness of wishes, on contentment, on effacement, on 1090  detachment.🔽Herein, the one who is an alms-food eater depending only on fewness of wishes, on contentment, on effacement, on detachment,

original: aggo ca seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.
analyzed: aggaḥ ca seṭṭhaḥ ca pāmokkhaḥ ca uttamaḥ ca pavaraḥ ca
translated: is the chief, the best, the foremost, the highest, the most excellent of these five kinds of alms-food eaters.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma gavā khīraṁ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṁ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo, sappimaṇḍaṁ tattha aggamakkhāyati;🔽evamevaṁ yvāyaṁ piṇḍapātiko appicchataṁyeva nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma gavā khīra khīramhā dadhi dadhimhā navanīta navanītamhā sappi sappimhā sappi maṇḍaḥ sappi maṇḍam tattha aggam akkhāyati  evam evam yvā ayam piṇḍapātikaḥ appiccha tayā iva nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva
translated: Just as ghee is supreme when extracted from milk, cream is supreme when extracted from ghee, butter is supreme when extracted from cream, curd is supreme when extracted from butter, and milk is supreme when extracted from curd,

original: nissāya idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya piṇḍapātiko hoti, ayaṁ imesaṁ pañcannaṁ piṇḍapātikānaṁ
analyzed: nissāya idam atthitayā iva nissāya piṇḍapātikaḥ hoti ayam imesam pañcannam
translated: so too, this alms-food-eater who is an alms-food-eater depending on fewness of wishes, depending on contentment, depending on solitude, depending on aloofness,

original: aggo ca seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.
analyzed: aggaḥ ca seṭṭhaḥ ca pāmokkhaḥ ca uttamaḥ ca pavaraḥ ca
translated: is the foremost, the best, the pre-eminent, the supreme, the most special of these five kinds of alms-food-eaters.

original: Ime pañca piṇḍapātikā.
analyzed: ime pañca piṇḍapātikā
translated: These are the five kinds of alms-food-eaters.

original: Tattha katame pañca khalupacchābhattikā …pe…
analyzed: tattha katame pañca khalu pacchābhattikā
translated: Herein, what are the five who eat what is thrown away? …

original: pañca ekāsanikā …pe…🔽pañca paṁsukūlikā …pe…
analyzed: pañca ekāsanikā pe  pañca pasukūlikā pe
translated: the five who eat in one session? …🔽the five who wear refuse rags? …

original: pañca tecīvarikā …pe…
analyzed: pañca tecīvarikā pe
translated: the five who wear any old thing? …🔽the five who live in the forest? …🔽the five who live at the foot of a tree? …

original: pañca āraññikā …pe…🔽pañca rukkhamūlikā …pe…
analyzed: pañca āraññikā pe  pañca rukkhamūlikā pe
translated: the five who live out in the open? …

original: pañca abbhokāsikā …pe…🔽pañca nesajjikā …pe…
analyzed: pañca abbhokāsikā pe  pañca nesajjikā pe
translated: the five who are perpetual sitters? …

original: pañca yathāsanthatikā …pe….
analyzed: pañca yathāsanthatikā pe
translated: the five who live wherever they lay their mat? …

original: Tattha katame pañca sosānikā?
analyzed: tattha katame pañca
translated: Herein, what are the five who live in a charnel ground?

original: Mandattā momūhattā sosāniko hoti, pāpiccho icchāpakato sosāniko hoti, ummādā cittavikkhepā🔽sosāniko hoti, “vaṇṇitaṁ buddhehi buddhasāvakehī”ti sosāniko hoti, api ca appicchataṁyeva
analyzed: manda ttā momūha ttā sosānikaḥ hoti pāpicchaḥ icchā pakataḥ sosānikaḥ hoti ummādā citta vikkhepā  sosānikaḥ hoti vaṇṇitam buddhehi buddha sāvakehi iti sosānikaḥ hoti api ca appiccha tayā iva
translated: He is a charnel-ground dweller because of dullness and stupidity; he is a charnel-ground dweller because of evil desires, because of mental confusion;🔽he is a charnel-ground dweller because of insanity, because of mental derangement; he is a charnel-ground dweller because of the praise of Buddhas and the praise of Buddhas’ disciples; he is a charnel-ground dweller because of the desire for non-affliction,

original: nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva nissāya idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya sosāniko hoti.🔽Tatra yvāyaṁ sosāniko appicchataṁyeva nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva
analyzed: nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva nissāya idam atthitayā iva nissāya sosānikaḥ hoti  tatra yvā ayam sosānikaḥ appiccha tayā iva nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva
translated: because of the desire for fewness of wishes, because of the desire for contentment, because of the desire for aloofness, because of the desire for seclusion, because of the desire for mental tranquillity, because of the desire for a gladdened mind, because of the desire for the knowledge and vision of the Way, because of the desire for the knowledge and vision of the Way’s culmination.

original: nissāya idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya sosāniko, ayaṁ imesaṁ pañcannaṁ sosānikānaṁ aggo
analyzed: nissāya idam atthi tayā iva nissāya sosānikaḥ ayam imesam pañcannam sosānikānam aggo
translated: Herein, the charnel-ground dweller who is a charnel-ground dweller because of the desire for non-affliction, because of the desire for fewness of wishes, because of the desire for contentment, because of the desire for aloofness, because of the desire for seclusion, because of the desire for mental tranquillity, because of the desire for a gladdened mind, because of the desire for the knowledge and vision of the Way, because of the desire for the knowledge and vision of the Way’s culmination, is the chief,

original: ca seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.
analyzed: ca seṭṭhaḥ ca pāmokkhaḥ ca uttamaḥ ca pavaraḥ ca
translated: the best, the foremost, the highest, the most excellent of these five kinds of charnel-ground dwellers.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma gavā khīraṁ, khīramhā dadhi, dadhimhā navanītaṁ, navanītamhā sappi, sappimhā sappimaṇḍo, sappimaṇḍaṁ tattha aggamakkhāyati;
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma gavā khīra khīramhā dadhi dadhimhā navanīta navanītamhā sappi sappimhā sappi maṇḍaḥ sappi maṇḍam tattha aggam akkhāyati
translated: Just as of cattle, namely, oxen, heifers, bulls, steers, and calves, the bull is the chief, the best, the foremost, the highest, the most excellent, so too, the charnel-ground dweller who is a charnel-ground dweller because of the desire for non-affliction … because of the desire for the knowledge and vision of the Way’s culmination, is the chief, the best, the foremost, the highest, the most excellent of these five kinds of charnel-ground dwellers.

original: evamevaṁ yvāyaṁ sosāniko appicchataṁyeva nissāya santuṭṭhiṁyeva nissāya sallekhaṁyeva
analyzed: evam evam yvā ayam sosānikaḥ appiccha tayā iva nissāya santuṭṭhiyā iva nissāya sallekhayā iva
translated: So too, there is the case where a certain one goes to the charnel ground out of fewness of desires…

original: nissāya idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya sosāniko hoti, ayaṁ imesaṁ pañcannaṁ sosānikānaṁ🔽aggo ca seṭṭho ca pāmokkho ca uttamo ca pavaro ca.🔽Ime pañca sosānikā.
analyzed: nissāya idam atthitayā iva nissāya sosānikaḥ hoti ayam imesam pañcannam sosānikāna  aggaḥ ca seṭṭhaḥ ca pāmokkhaḥ ca uttamaḥ ca pavaraḥ ca  ime pañca sosānikā
translated: This is the foremost of the five kinds of charnel-ground dwellers, the best, the most excellent, the most refined, the supreme, the most special.

original: Pañcakaniddeso.
translated: These are the five kinds of charnel-ground dwellers.🔽The Description of the Fives is finished.
